{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3323955,"name":"Avi","username":"Avi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avi/{size}/214903_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T23:33:32.723Z","cooked":"

When I run our flywheels using REV they work perfectly getting to exactly the desired RPM in no time, but when I use our code (in which we’re using the CANSparkMAX PidController) the flywheels go at like half the speed.

Why might this be?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-04T23:33:32.723Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":123.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457280,"topic_slug":"rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code","display_username":"Avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55766,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code/457280/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3323959,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T23:36:30.681Z","cooked":"

Can you share a link to your code? And maybe a screenshot of it working in the REV hardware client?

The graph is just they overshoot a little and then settle at our target (right now 4000rpm). When I run the code both REV client and AdvantageScope w/ values from the NEO relative encoders read an RPM of around 2000.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-05T00:40:14.145Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457280,"topic_slug":"rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code","display_username":"Avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20021,"username":"Chadfrom7226","name":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55766,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code/457280/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3324403,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T14:58:09.459Z","cooked":"

I do notice you don’t set your PID values in your shooter subsystem, which is not recommended in case you need to swap out a SparkMAX.

I do think you have everything correct in your code though, assuming your PID values are correct. I would try putting your PID values in code:

github.com

REVrobotics/SPARK-MAX-Examples/blob/b865e5fa644bc859769c7a6130b7101176aec6d5/Java/Velocity Closed Loop Control/src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java#L66


      
    
          
  1. kP = 6e-5; 
    2. 
          
  2. kI = 0;
    3. 
          
  3. kD = 0; 
    4. 
          
  4. kIz = 0; 
    5. 
          
  5. kFF = 0.000015; 
    6. 
          
  6. kMaxOutput = 1; 
    7. 
          
  7. kMinOutput = -1;
    8. 
          
  8. maxRPM = 5700;
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10. // set PID coefficients
    11. 
          
  11. m_pidController.setP(kP);
    12. 
          
  12. m_pidController.setI(kI);
    13. 
          
  13. m_pidController.setD(kD);
    14. 
          
  14. m_pidController.setIZone(kIz);
    15. 
          
  15. m_pidController.setFF(kFF);
    16. 
          
  16. m_pidController.setOutputRange(kMinOutput, kMaxOutput);
    17. 
          
  17. 
          
  18. // display PID coefficients on SmartDashboard
    19. 
          
  19. SmartDashboard.putNumber("P Gain", kP);
    20. 
          
  20. SmartDashboard.putNumber("I Gain", kI);
    21. 
          
  21. SmartDashboard.putNumber("D Gain", kD);
    22.

But that still doesn’t explain the problem, right? Because if the PID constants were wrong then the flywheels either wouldn’t spin or would oscillate like crazy. Instead they precisely go to half the desired speed

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-06T15:53:02.396Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":20.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457280,"topic_slug":"rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code","display_username":"Avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20021,"username":"Chadfrom7226","name":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55766,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code/457280/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326646,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T09:31:37.943Z","cooked":"

Not sure, but in the process of hard coding your PID, you might find out the underlying issue. It’s good practice anyways

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T09:31:37.943Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":70,"readers_count":69,"score":14.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457280,"topic_slug":"rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55766,"username":"Avi","name":"Avi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avi/{size}/214903_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code/457280/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3326701,"name":"Basel Alghanem","username":"Basel_A","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/basel_a/{size}/65204_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T13:27:25.578Z","cooked":"
Avi:

When I run the code both REV client and AdvantageScope w/ values from the NEO relative encoders read an RPM of around 2000.

Is there a way for you to see the reference (aka the target)? Simplest explanation would be a different target rpm is getting set than you expected

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T13:27:25.578Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":60,"readers_count":59,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457280,"topic_slug":"rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code","display_username":"Basel Alghanem","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12479,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code/457280/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327081,"name":"Avi","username":"Avi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avi/{size}/214903_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T19:34:22.782Z","cooked":"

The sparkpidcontroller doesn’t have a getSetpoint() method. These desiredSpeed entries though are accurate, so I’m pretty sure it’s at the right setpoint.

Screenshot 2024-03-07 at 11.31.00 AM1102×190 43.1 KB

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T19:34:22.782Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":40,"readers_count":39,"score":13.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457280,"topic_slug":"rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code","display_username":"Avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/a/daf8c689f81219d60269cf5da4ffd2d5f265f540.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12479,"username":"Basel_A","name":"Basel Alghanem","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/basel_a/{size}/65204_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55766,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-hardware-client-inconsistencies-with-code/457280/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327586,"name":"Basel Alghanem","username":"Basel_A","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/basel_a/{size}/65204_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T04:29:43.664Z","cooked":"

I think I agree unless it’s somehow fighting intakeNote which also sets that setpoint.

Setpoint difference just feels like the most obvious possible way it could be failing, could easily be something more subtle.
